conversation.content: I can't believe you're making me do this at 6 AM.
[very quickly] One two three four five okay slow down! You're going too fast on those reps. We want controlled movements here, not a race to the finish.
My legs are already burning.
That's the lactic acid building up, totally normal. Six, seven, eight. Your form is actually looking better than last week though.
You said that last week too.
Nine, ten, and I meant it both times! Eleven, twelve. You've been consistently improving your hip alignment during squats.
How many more?
Thirteen, fourteen, fifteen. We're going to twenty today, then straight into lunges. Your cardiovascular endurance has improved enough to handle the back-to-back sets.
Twenty? You said fifteen yesterday!
Sixteen, seventeen. Yesterday was a recovery day, today we're pushing boundaries. Eighteen, your knees are caving slightly, push them out.
I hate lunges.
Nineteen, twenty, excellent! Everyone hates lunges until they see what they do for their glutes and quads. Ready for the next set?
Can we take a water break?
Thirty seconds, hydrate and shake it out. Your heart rate is at 145, which is perfect for your target zone. We want to maintain that intensity.
[child-like] But my legs feel like jello!
That jello feeling means you're recruiting muscle fibers you don't normally use. One, two, three on the lunges now. Keep that back straight.
Why do you count so slowly during lunges?
Four, five, six. Because time under tension builds more muscle than rushing through movements. Seven, eight, you're tilting forward again.
[condescending] I know what I'm doing.
Nine, ten, clearly you do, which is why your knee just went past your toes. Eleven, twelve, let's reset that form before you hurt yourself.
